review_title: A great place to spend 5 days a week
job_title: Relationship Specialist in High Wycombe, England
pros: Red Kite is great at giving their staff the opportunity to put their ideas forward and help shape the services that we deliver; this helps to promote an environment where I feel that voices are heard and where we have the chance to progress upwards within the organisation. There's a genuine effort to put tenants at the heart of everything that we do and to continuously improve. Having worked in office environments that stifle creativity and are happy to do the same things day in day out regardless of how effective they are, it is a breath of fresh air to know that if I see a way to improve a process, I have the freedom to try it. The staff as a whole work well together and there's a real sense of fun at work, which is important as I spend a lot of my time here.
cons: There really aren't that many that I can think of. Any concerns that I have had over the past two years of working here have all been or are being addressed in really positive ways, so I wouldn't want to put them down as cons. I'd say the only thing that I can think of is that sometimes there's so many ideas that some of them get put to one side while others are pursued; so maybe just a little more focus. That's hardly a criticism though.

pros:
Dynamic business totally committed to its tenants 
Strong and visionary management team focused on improvement and fairness
Great offices with time for individuals to personally develop and grow.
Friendly culture and a strong sense of purpose
Staff (where possible) are allowed to work flexibly and are trusted to do a good job
Value for money is very strong and as such it is a challenging culture, waste is frowned upon and not accepted
Strong Board who understand the business and are friendly, polite and interact with staff
inspiring and challenging place to work
Don't apply to work for this great organisation if you want an easy life or are not good at what you do 
This is an organisation for the motivated, non stereotypical housing  professional
cons:
Some less capable  find it difficult to match the high standards expected 
Plenty of staff benefits 
Great opportunists if you have the right attitude and will to deliver great service

review_title: Genuinely a great place to work - strong values
job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Wycombe, England
pros: Red Kite is a very different place to work than your average office environment in that they try to be creative and unique but for all the right reasons. It's not just for the sake of it. I really do think that the management and leadership are genuine and provide good leadership, always trying to be innovative in a sector that is quite traditional normally. The environment is great, a professional yet casual and friendly atmosphere and people are in the main all really approachable. I have found that it's the kind of place that if you apply yourself and have a positive attitude, you will go places, but if you don't then you'll soon be found out.  They're strong on their values and it's definitely a great place to work.
cons: Not too many really.  I'd say like everywhere there are some areas for improvement (less emails for example) but it's the kind of place that if people bothered to speak up about things, they would genuinely do what they can about those issues. One thing I would say is a bit of a downer that can't be helped is that parking at the office isn't great, but that's fairly common most places these days I think.  Another would be that I've never worked anywhere else where I've had as much opportunity or empowerment given to me as there is at Red Kite, but sadly some staff don't take up that opportunity, which is a real shame.

pros:
The offices are presentable, clean and very inviting. 

People who do the ground work are approachable, work hand and are not afraid to go an extra mile to help. 

Attempting a modern approach on Social Housing. 

Good balance of young and mature employees.
cons:
Parking facilities leave a lot to be desired. And office favourites only will get to park on-site. 

Working from the top down: 
The CEO is rarely there, and his presence is so insignificant that an involved tenant was mistaken for the CEO on several occasions. In my time at Red Kite the CEO didn't demonstrate a great deal of leadership, an ability to empower staff, charisma or "people skills" and it felt like he was severely bossed around by the Chairman which didn't give the staff a lot of faith in our values. 

There has been too much of micro-management which did nothing good for the company and it's progress.

People who work "hand-on" are often treated dismissively and there is a severe lack of communication between people who run projects and people who the projects will actually affect. 

Recruitment is often set up with people in mind already and the fact that jobs go out to advert is just a cover up for that.  People who just turn up out of the blue seem to get very far very quickly simply because they "know people" 

And finally the money is being wasted on things/ projects that were not thought out well enough to even start them.

job_title: Project Manager in High Wycombe, England
pros: Magnificent head office office and flexibility working remotely in various satalite offices. Very keen and good quality  front line staff. Strong financially. Property stock very heavily invested in.
cons:
Senior management and executive teams do not lead by example on the values they set. Over the past 2 years they have tried to implement to many many system based projects at a time, this has lead to the majority of them failing and not producing the outcomes they promised. Many departments stretched due to this and its very evident that this has lead to a blame culture around the organisation. The board are very influenced by certain exec team members without the realisation of what is going on, on the ground. Very high turnover of staff approx 220 in 5 years. A lot of recruiting agencies are aware of the negative culture Red Kite now has and find it difficult to put forward proven/loyal candidates without miss-selling them. HR are arms length and do not have the qualities or experience to deal with basic issues which turn into problems. Very inconsistent on policies and Procedures which makes your daily working more difficult than it needs to be.
SMT management need to work with each other and not against - this has proven to be the case leading to unnecessary pressures which eventually filter down to staff.
